review_title: Extremely flexible but super low pay
job_title: Student Research Assistant in Provo, UT
pros:
I can work any hour of the day, since they just let me clock in over the phone.
The research is fascinating, and the educational opportunity is fantasic since it's right in line with what I want to do for a career.
cons:
This is the highest research assistant wage I've seen at byu, but since housing prices have doubled in the last decade in provo, and a large part of that increase was over covid, the wage isn't near enough to pay for basic living expenses. My wife and I both work part time here, and it's not enough to even pay rent. 
The only way BYU can pay so low is because the students are surviving off of student loans.
The lower paying campus jobs are feeling the impact of low wages, first, and their response is tacky ads all over campus advertising custodial jobs, and the restaurants in the food courts are all closed for the majority of the day, since they can't hire anybody.

review_title: I worked with Campus Floral for a few years on BYU campus as a student
pros:
Easy commute from school or apartment (In Provo)
New friends with similar age and experience
Easy to learn systems and protocol
Learn about running a small business
Relatively flexible schedule
cons:
Very hard to move up the company and be trained for new positions. Managers have their favorite people and like to keep you in your place. 
Unclear about starting pay! They were "training" me for a year with a lower income than advertised. 
Not sustainable pay for adults. You get a 25 cent raise every semester or year.

review_title: BYU Marriott Business Career Center: Best Job at BYU
job_title: Client Success Specialist in Mobile, AL
pros:
An amazing environment where you can learn and grow professionally and become a better person

The culture is collaborative and inclusive. Your coworkers immediately become your friends

If you want to be better prepared to enter your career path after graduation, learning professional communication skills and time management, this is a great job to have

Genuinely my favorite part of my BYU experience

Great hourly pay

Your boss genuinely cares about you and your well-being and will help you when you feel like you're struggling
cons:
It is a time commitment and the job does have a learning curve.

You need to work 20 hrs/week in 4-hour shifts M-F, so it can be tough to coordinate your school schedule.

There are no opportunities to work full-time at the BCC after graduation, but you do get the chance to network with many recruiters from different companies and it presents a great opportunity to find a great job that way

pros:

-Pay is minimal for the duties we undertake

It seems that most people on campus want to be inclusive and to create a place where everyone feels a sense of belonging, but that doesn't mean that we all have the skills and experience to make this happen the way we wish we could. review_title: Good colleagues and atmosphere, poor faculty to administrator communication
pros: The high moral standards are refreshing.  I have never needed to deal with alcohol, drugs, or sexual issues and rarely with cheating.  The collegial relationships with other faculty are excellent, and interactions with lower-level leadership (chairs, deans) are general very good.  Compensation is good, though somewhat tempered by the long hours.  The university provides good access to current technology and other resources.
cons:
My primary issue with BYU-Idaho is the total lack of a legitimate means of communication from faculty to administration.  Transformational programs and policies have been enacted since I began teaching here with absolutely no attempt to elicit faculty feedback on any of them.  The Faculty Association has tried to represent concerns of faculty and, as a result, has lost its official status on campus.  The only formal means we have to communicate with the administration are: 1) pass it up through the department chair; 2) submit questions by email that they may or may not choose to address, and if they do it is to "instruct" the faculty member; and, most recently, post on Facebook, which may be removed if it reflects negatively on the university.  This has led to a highly cynical faculty that feels completely detached from the decision-making process at the university.

The other primary concern has to do with work load.  Twelve hours of teaching per semester for three semesters a year.  No load release is given for committee or other assignments.  Many of us work 60+ hours per week without additional compensation.

pros: It was a fun environment to learn professional skills in AV productions. I'd recommend it as a stepping stone for people who want to get into that industry and gain valuable experience. Many of the full-time staff have connections to professional AV companies all over the country. If you were there a long time the raises added up, making it one of the best paid student jobs on campus. We also didn't have to abide by the 20 hour per week rule, the nature of live events required lots of hours around the big events each year, which meant nice paychecks for the part-time students.
cons:
The bureaucracy and red tape was really frustrating at times, it was hard to have clients trust us because of all the rules that management imposed. When we tried to step away from the red tape and rules we always had clients happy with our work. I was also very frustrated with the pace at which important decisions were made, it seemed like BYU was determined to committee everything to death instead of make decisions. 
It was also frustrating that we often times had to drop everything and answer for an emergency but weren't paid like the rest of the industry was. There was no hour minimum, meaning sometimes I'd get a phone call at midnight, go over to the Marriott Center to do 10 minutes of work and only get paid for that 10 minutes. That was frustrating.
